revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}}[[File:TTUSWlibrary.JPG|thumb|Southwest Collections / Special Collections Library at [[Texas Tech University|Texas Tech]], a university in the United States]] [[File:Leiden 1694.jpg|right|thumb|University Library Leiden, the Netherlands, in 1694. La nouvelle bibliothèque, from ''Les delices de Leide, une des célèbres villes de l'Europe'', Leiden: P. van der Aa, 1712]] [[File:Cmglee London Maughan Library reading room.jpg|thumb|The round reading room of [[Maughan Library]], the main university library of [[King's College London]]]] [[File:Sofia university library.jpg|thumb|right|The interior of [[Sofia University]]'s main library.]] [[File:Glasgow University Library 000 0124.jpg|thumb|The Main Library Building, University of Glasgow, with the Round Reading Room in the foreground]] [[File:Normal Uni-Bibliothek.jpg|thumb|right|The main building of the [[Heidelberg University]] Library, built in 1905]] [[File:UrisLibrary24.jpg|right|thumb|[[Uris Library]] and [[McGraw Tower]], Cornell University]] [[File:Univerzitetska bibloteka.jpg|thumb|[[Belgrade University Library]], a [[Carnegie library]]]] An '''academic library''' is a [[library]] that is attached to a higher education institution which serves two complementary purposes to support the school's curriculum, and to support the research of the university faculty and students.<ref name="Encyclopedia of Library and Information Science">{{cite journal|last=Curzon|first=Susan|author2=Jennie Quinonez-Skinner|title=Academic Libraries|journal=Encyclopedia of Library and Information Sciences|date=9 September 2009|doi=10.1081/E-ELIS3-120044525|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1081/E-ELIS3-120044390|accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref> It is unknown how many academic libraries there are internationally. An academic and research portal maintained by [[UNESCO]] links to 3,785 libraries. According to the [[National Center for Education Statistics]], there are an estimated 3,700 academic libraries in the United States.<ref name="Encyclopedia of Library and Information Science" /> The support of teaching and learning requires material for class readings and for student papers. In the past, the material for class readings, intended to supplement lectures as prescribed by the instructor, has been called reserves. In the period before electronic resources became available, the reserves were supplied as actual books or as photocopies of appropriate journal articles.
Academic libraries must determine a focus for collection development since comprehensive collections are not feasible. Librarians do this by identifying the needs of the faculty and student body, as well as the mission and academic programs of the college or university. When there are particular areas of specialization in academic libraries, these are often referred to as [[niche collections]]. These collections are often the basis of a [[Special collections|special collection]] department and may include original papers, artwork, and artifacts written or created by a single author or about a specific subject.
There is a great deal of variation among academic libraries based on their size, resources, collections, and services. The [[Harvard Library|Harvard University Library]] is considered to be the largest strict academic library in the world,<ref>{{cite book |last=Pezzi |first=Bryan |title=Massachusetts |publisher=Weigl Publishers |year=2000 |page=15 |isbn=1-930954-35-2}}</ref> although the [[Royal Library, Denmark|Danish Royal Library]]—a combined [[National library|national]] and academic library—has a larger collection.<ref>{{cite web|year=2015|url=http://www.kb.dk/export/sites/kb_dk/da/kb/aarsberetning/aarsberetninger/2015.pdf|title=Årsberetning 2015|accessdate=2017-08-28|language=Danish}}</ref> Another notable example is the [[University of the South Pacific]] which has academic libraries distributed throughout its twelve member countries.<ref name="Encyclopedia of Library and Information Science" /> The [[University of California]] operates the largest academic library system in the world, it manages more than 34 million items in 100 libraries on ten campuses.
==History== {{globalize|date=August 2017}} ===United States=== {{see also|University libraries in the United States}} The first colleges in the United States were intended to train members of the clergy. The libraries associated with these institutions largely consisted of donated books on the subjects of theology and the classics. In 1766, [[Yale University|Yale]] had approximately 4,000 volumes, second only to [[Harvard University|Harvard]].<ref> {{cite book | last=Budd | first = John M.| title = The Academic Library: Its Context, Its Purpose, and Its Operation| publisher = Libraries Unlimited| year = 1998| location = Englewood, Colorado| pages = 30–31| isbn = }}</ref> Access to these libraries was restricted to faculty members and a few students: the only staff was a part-time faculty member or the president of the college.<ref> {{cite book| last = McCabe | first = Gerard|author2= Ruth J. Person| title = Academic Libraries: Their Rationale and Role in American Higher Education | publisher = Greenwood Press| year = 1995| location = Westport, Connecticut| pages = 1–3| isbn = }}</ref> The priority of the library was to protect the books, not to allow patrons to use them. In 1849, [[Yale University|Yale]] was open 30 hours a week, the [[University of Virginia]] was open nine hours a week, [[Columbia University]] four, and [[Bowdoin College]] only three.<ref name="Budd 1998, p. 34">Budd (1998), p. 34</ref> Students instead created [[Literary society|literary societies]] and assessed entrance fees in order to build a small collection of usable volumes often in excess of what the university library held.<ref name="Budd 1998, p. 34"/>
Around the turn of the century, this approach began to change. The [[American Library Association]] was formed in 1876, with members including [[Melvil Dewey]] and [[Charles Ammi Cutter]]. Libraries re-prioritized in favor of improving access to materials, and found funding increasing as a result of increased demand for said materials.<ref>McCabe (1995), pp. 1-3.</ref>
Academic libraries today vary in regard to the extent to which they accommodate those who are not affiliated with their parent universities. Some offer reading and borrowing privileges to members of the public on payment of an annual fee; such fees can vary greatly. The privileges so obtained usually do not extend to such services as computer usage, other than to search the catalog, or Internet access. Alumni and students of cooperating local universities may be given discounts or other consideration when arranging for borrowing privileges. On the other hand, access to the libraries of some universities is absolutely restricted to students, faculty, and staff. Even in this case, they may make it possible for others to borrow materials through inter-library loan programs.
Libraries of land-grant universities generally are more accessible to the public. In some cases, they are official government document repositories and so are required to be open to the public. Still, members of the public are generally charged fees for borrowing privileges, and usually are not allowed to access everything they would be able to as students.
===Canada=== Academic libraries in Canada are a relatively recent development in relation to other countries. The very first academic library in Canada was opened in 1789 in Windsor, Nova Scotia.<ref name="Beckman, M. 2010">{{cite web|title=Libraries|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0004674|author=Beckman, M.|author2=Dahms, M.|author3=Lorne, B.|year=2010}}</ref> Academic libraries were significantly small during the 19th century and up until the 1950s, when Canadian academic libraries began to grow steadily as a result of greater importance being placed on education and research.<ref name="Beckman, M. 2010"/> The growth of libraries throughout the 1960s was a direct result of many overwhelming factors including inflated student enrollments, increased graduate programs, higher budget allowance, and general advocacy of the importance of these libraries.<ref>{{cite book|last=Downs|first=R. B.|title=Resources of canadian academic and research libraries|year=1967|publisher=Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada|location=Ottawa, ON.|pages=9}}</ref> As a result of this growth and the Ontario New Universities Library Project that occurred during the early 1960s, 5 new universities were established in Ontario that all included fully catalogued collections.<ref name="Beckman, M. 2010"/> The establishment of libraries was widespread throughout Canada and was furthered by grants provided by the Canada Council and the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council, which sought to enhance library collections.<ref name="Beckman, M. 2010"/> Since many academic libraries were constructed after World War Two, a majority of the Canadian academic libraries that were built before 1940 that have not been updated to modern lighting, air conditioning, etc., are either no longer in use or are on the verge of decline.<ref>{{cite book|last=Downs|first=R. B.|title=Resources of canadian academic and research libraries|year=1967|publisher=Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada|location=Ottawa, ON.|pages=93}}</ref> The total number of college and university libraries increased from 31 in 1959-1960 to 105 in 1969-1970.<ref>{{cite book|last=Downs|first=R. B.|title=Resources of canadian academic and research libraries|year=1967|publisher=Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada|location=Ottawa, ON.|pages=4}}</ref>
Following the growth of academic libraries in Canada during the 1960s, there was a brief period of sedation, which was a primary result of some major budgetary issues.<ref name="The Canada Council">{{cite book|title=University research libraries: Report of the consultative group on university research libraries|year=1978|publisher=The Canada Council|location=Ottawa, ON|pages=4}}</ref> These academic libraries were faced with cost issues relating to the recently developed service of interlibrary lending and the high costs of periodicals on acquisition budgets, which affected overall acquisition budgeting and ultimately general collections.<ref name="The Canada Council"/> Canadian academic libraries faced consistent problems relating to insufficient collections and overall lack of coordination among collections.<ref>{{cite book|title=University research libraries: Report of the consultative group on university research libraries|year=1978|publisher=The Canada Council|location=Ottawa, ON|pages=2}}</ref>
Academic libraries within Canada would not have flourished and continue to be strengthened without the help of outside organizations. The Ontario Council of University Libraries (OCUL) was established in 1967 and is concerned with promoting unity among Canadian academic libraries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ocul.on.ca/node/25|title=A History of Collaboration|first=|date=|year=2011|website=Ontario Council of University Libraries|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120826054848/http://www.ocul.on.ca/node/25|archive-date=2012-08-26|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-02-17|author=}}</ref> The Ontario College and University Library Association (OCULA) is attached to the Ontario Library Association (OLA) and is concerned with representing academic librarians in regards to issues that are shared in the academic library setting.<ref>{{cite web|title=About OCULA |url=http://www.accessola.org/ola_prod/OLAWEB/OCULA/About_OCULA/OLAWEB/OCULA/About_OCULA.aspx |author=Ontario Library Association |year=n.d. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111206012959/http://www.accessola.org/ola_prod/OLAWEB/OCULA/About_OCULA/OLAWEB/OCULA/About_OCULA.aspx |archivedate=6 December 2011 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Academic journal]] * [[Google Scholar and academic libraries]] * [[Internet search engines and libraries]] * [[Research library]] * [[Research Libraries Group]] * [[Research Libraries UK]] * [[Library assessment]] * [[Trends in library usage]]

==Further reading== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140812205104/http://www.arbido.ch/fr/artikel_detail.php?m=3&id=1560&n=121 Jürgen Beyer, « Comparer les bibliothèques universitaires », ''Arbido newsletter'' 2012:8] * Ellsworth, Ralph E. (1973) ''Academic library buildings: a guide to architectural issues and solutions'' 530 pp. Boulder: Associated University Press * Giustini, Dean (2011, 3 May) Canadian academic libraries' use of social media, 2011 update [Web log post]. Retrieved from http://blogs.ubc.ca/dean/2011/05/canadian-academic-libraries-use-of-social-media-2011-update/ *Hamlin, Arthur T. (1981). ''The University Library in the United States: Its Origins and Development.'' Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. {{ISBN|9780812277951}} *Hunt, C. J. (1993) "Academic library planning in the United Kingdom", in: ''British Journal of Academic Librarianship''; vol. 8 (1993), pp. 3–16 *Shiflett, Orvin Lee (1981). ''Origins of American Academic Librarianship.'' Norwood, N.J.: Ablex Pub. Corp. {{ISBN|9780893910822}} * Taylor, Sue, ed. (1995) ''Building libraries for the information age: based on the proceedings of a symposium on The Future of Higher Educational Libraries at the King's Manor, York 11–12 April 1994''. York: Institute of Advanced Architectural Studies, University of York {{ISBN|0-904761-49-5}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox writer | name = Alexander Chee | image = Alexander Chee 2018.jpg | imagesize = | alt = | caption = Chee at the 2018 Texas Book Festival | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = August 21, 1967 | birth_place = South Kingston, [[Rhode Island]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Writer]] | nationality = American | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | notableworks = ''[[Edinburgh (novel)|Edinburgh]]'' | spouse = | partner = | children = }} '''Alexander Chee''' is an American fiction writer, poet, journalist and reviewer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsletter.blogs.wesleyan.edu/2010/06/28/writers-conference-draws-novelists-poets-journalists/ |title=Writers Conference Draws Novelists, Poets, Journalists |publisher=Newsletter.blogs.wesleyan.edu |date=2010-06-28 |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref>
Born in [[Rhode Island]], he spent his childhood in [[South Korea]], [[Kauai]], [[Chuuk Lagoon|Truk]], [[Guam]] and [[Maine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.guernicamag.com/korean_enough_new_korean_ameri/|title=Korean Enough: Alexander Chee on New Korean American Fiction - Guernica|website=www.guernicamag.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-22}}</ref> He attended [[Wesleyan University]] and the [[Iowa Writers' Workshop]].
==Career== Chee's short fiction appeared in the anthologies ''Best American Erotica 2007, A Fictional History of the US (With Huge Chunks Missing), Men on Men 2000'', ''His 3,'' and his personal essays in'' OutFrom Boys To Men, Loss Within Loss, Boys Like Us, The M Word,'' and ''The Man I Might Become.'' His essay "I, Reader" was selected for inclusion in the Notable Essays list of the 2011 edition of the ''Best American Essays'',<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=43XFNtW8qmYC&pg=PA234&lpg=PA234&dq=%22Alexander+Chee%22+and+%22Best+American+Essays%22&source=bl&ots=8feupJ1Gir&sig=QqoX_5jaqs-qYMw59I4BHz5mSRQ&hl=en&ei=fIKXTsP0EMPv0gHUu4zpBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=The Best American Essays 2011 – Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.themorningnews.org/article/i-reader |title=I, Reader |publisher=The Morning News |date=2007-11-21 |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> and his essay "Girl," was included in ''[[The Best American Essays|Best American Essays 2016.]]''<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://english.dartmouth.edu/people/alexander-chee|title=Alexander Chee {{!}} Department of English and Creative Writing|website=english.dartmouth.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-09-22}}</ref>
His short stories and essays have also appeared in magazines and journals such as ''[[The New York Times Book Review]], [[Tin House]], [[Slate (magazine)|Slate]], [[Guernica (magazine)|Guernica]], [[NPR]]''. Chee's poetry has appeared in ''[[Barrow Street (magazine)|Barrow Street]]'', ''LIT'', ''[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]]'', the ''[[James White Review]]'', and ''XXX Fruit''.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://koreanish.wordpress.com/bio/|title=Bio|date=2015-03-11|work=Koreanish|access-date=2017-09-22|language=en-US}}</ref> He has written journalism and reviews for ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Sunday Book Review – The Leftovers: ''Everything I Never Told You'' by Celeste Ng|first=Alexander|last=Chee|date=August 15, 2014|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/17/books/review/everything-i-never-told-you-by-celeste-ng.html|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> ''[[Time Out (company)|Time Out New York]]'', ''[[Outlook (magazine)|Out/Look]]'', ''[[OutWeek]]'', ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]'', ''[[Out (magazine)|Out]]'', ''[[Bookforum]]'' and the ''[[San Francisco Review of Books]]''.
Chee's critically acclaimed debut novel ''[[Edinburgh (novel)|Edinburgh]]'' was awarded the [[Asian American Writers' Workshop|Asian American Writers Workshop Literary Award]], the [[Lambda Literary Award|Lambda Editor's Choice Prize]], and the [[Michener-Copernicus Fellowship|Michener/Copernicus Fellowship Prize]]. In 2003, ''[[Out (magazine)|Out]]'' named Chee one of their 100 Most Influential People of the year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.arts.gov/writers-corner/bio/alexander-chee|title=Alexander Chee {{!}} NEA|website=www.arts.gov|access-date=2017-09-22}}</ref>
He was also the recipient of the 2003 [[Whiting Awards|Whiting Award]], a 2004 [[NEA fellowship|NEA Fellowship]], and a 2010 Massachusetts Cultural Council of the Arts Fellowship, as well as residency fellowships at the [[MacDowell Colony]], the Virginia Center for Creative Arts, [[Civitella Ranieri Foundation|Civitella Ranieri]], and [[Ledig House|Leidig House]].<ref name=":0" /> He was a judge for the [[PEN/Open Book]] award in 2012<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pen.org/blog/announcing-2012-pen-literary-awards-recipients |title=Announcing the 2012 PEN Literary Award Recipients |date=October 15, 2012 |accessdate=February 6, 2013 |work=[[PEN American Center]]}}</ref> and currently serves on the [[board of directors]] of the Authors' Guild of America.
Chee was the associate fiction editor of literary magazine ''[[The Nervous Breakdown (magazine)|The Nervous Breakdown]]'', and is currently a [[contributing editor]] at ''[[The New Republic]]'', an [[editor-at-large]] at ''[[Virginia Quarterly Review|VQR]] ''and ''The Lit Hub,'' and a critic-at-large for ''[[Los Angeles Times|The Los Angeles Times]]''.
He has taught fiction writing at the [[New School University]], [[Wesleyan University|Wesleyan]], [[Iowa Writers' Workshop|University of Iowa Writers’ Workshop]], [[Columbia University]], the [[University of Texas at Austin]] and [[Princeton University]],<ref name=":1" /> and has served as a Visiting Writer at [[Amherst College]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Novelist and Amherst College Visiting Writer Alexander Chee to Read from His Work at Amherst Books April 29|date=April 8, 2010|url=https://www.amherst.edu/aboutamherst/news/news_releases/2010/04/node/189751|work=[[Amherst College]]}}</ref> In the winter semester 2012/2013 he was Picador Professor for Literature at the [[University of Leipzig]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americanstudies.uni-leipzig.de/picador |title=The Picador Guest Professorship for Literature | American Studies Leipzig |publisher=Americanstudies.uni-leipzig.de |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> Chee is currently associate professor of creative nonfiction and fiction writing at [[Dartmouth College]] in Hanover, New Hampshire.<ref name=":0" />
==Works==
===Books=== * 2001: ''[[Edinburgh (novel)|Edinburgh]]'', [[Picador USA]], {{ISBN|978-0-31230-503-1}} * 2016: {{cite book |date=2016 |title=The Queen of the Night |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mKQ7mgEACAAJ&dq=9780618663026&hl=en&sa=X&ei=CAMRVKCEFvTbsASN-YI4&ved=0CBQQ6AEwAA |publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]]|isbn=978-0-618-66302-6 }} * 2018: ''How to Write an Autobiographical Novel'' (April 17, 2018), [[Mariner Books]], {{ISBN|978-1328764522}}
===Anthologies=== * {{cite book |date=1990 |title=Literature of Tomorrow |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ee1ZAAAAMAAJ&q=literature+of+tomorrow&dq=literature+of+tomorrow&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAGoVChMI6d-mrvDqxwIVBVQ-Ch1Pag70 |publisher=Holt, Rinehart, and Winston |chapter=Memorials |isbn=978-0-03032-903-6 }} * {{cite book |date=1996 |editor=Patrick Merla |title=Boys Like Us: Gay Writers Tell Their Coming Out Stories |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-YWAjZd3c88C&printsec=frontcover&dq=boys+like+us+gay+writers&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAGoVChMI2PXO4_DqxwIVwzg-Ch2_cAT0#v=onepage&q&f=false |publisher=Avon Books |chapter= |isbn=978-0-38097-340-8 }} * {{cite book |date=1999 |title=His(3): Brilliant New Fiction by Gay Writers |url= |publisher=Faber & Faber |isbn=978-0-57119-963-1 }} * {{cite book |date=2004 |title=The "M" Word: Writers on Same-Sex Marriage |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0jOS_ToUYikC&printsec=frontcover&dq=the+m+word&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAWoVChMIv9SV1e_qxwIVgtk-Ch0K8Abz#v=onepage&q=the%20m%20word&f=false |publisher=Algonquin Books |isbn=978-1-56512-454-7 |chapter=41, 42, 43 }} * {{cite book |date=2006 |title=From Boys to Men: Gay Men Write About Growing Up |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AVb0iD00SqMC&printsec=frontcover&dq=from+boys+to+men+gay+men+write+about+growing+up&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAGoVChMI-f2yqPLqxwIVQ3YeCh16ZwLl#v=onepage&q&f=false |chapter=Dick |publisher=Da Capo Press |isbn=978-0-78671-632-6 }}
===Essays and stories=== *{{cite web |url=https://granta.com/portrait-of-my-father-chee/ |title=Portrait of My Father |date=12 March 2009 |website=Granta |publisher= }} *{{cite web |url=http://www.themorningnews.org/article/go-away |title=Go Away |date=13 August 2012 |website=The Morning News |publisher= }} *{{cite journal |date=Winter 2014 |title=Mr. and Mrs. B |url=http://blog.longreads.com/2015/06/18/mr-and-mrs-b/ |journal=Apology Magazine |volume=3 |issue= |publisher= }} *{{cite web |url=https://www.guernicamag.com/features/girl/ |title=Girl |date=16 March 2015 |website=Guernica: A Magazine of Art and Politics |publisher= }}
===Film appearances=== *Interview in ''Sex Is...'' (1993), Directed by [[Marc Huestis]], as himself

{{Infobox University | name = Alice Lloyd College | image_name = Alice Lloyd buildings.jpg | image_size = | established = 1923 | type = Private, four-year | endowment = $43.0 million (2018){{cite web|title=Alice Lloyd College|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/alice-lloyd-college-1951|publisher=[[U.S. News & World Report]]|accessdate=14 May 2016}} | president = Joe Alan Stepp | students = 599https://www.usnews.com/best-colleges/alice-lloyd-college-1951 | city = [[Pippa Passes, Kentucky|Pippa Passes]] | state = [[Kentucky]] | country = [[United States]] | campus = [[Rural area|Rural]], 175 acres (0.71 km²){{cite web|url=http://www.alc.edu/about/about_location.php|title=Location of Alice Lloyd College|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=24 April 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421011624/http://www.alc.edu/about/about_location.php|archivedate=21 April 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} | colors = {{color box|Blue}} {{color box|white}} | nickname = Eagles | mascot = Talon | affiliations = [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics]]
[[River States Conference]] | website = {{URL|www.alc.edu}} | logo = [[File:Alicelloyd.jpg|border|250px]] }} '''Alice Lloyd College''' is a four-year [[boarding school|boarding school-style]] [[liberal-arts college|liberal arts]] [[work college]] in [[Pippa Passes, Kentucky]], [[United States]]. It was co-founded by the journalist [[Alice Spencer Geddes Lloyd]] (a native of [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]) and [[June Buchanan]] (a native of [[New York City]]) in 1923, at first under the name of Caney Junior College. Founded as an institution to educate leaders in [[Appalachia]] locally, it became a four-year, [[bachelor's degree]]-granting institution in the early 1980s. Alice Lloyd College is [[educational accreditation|accredited]] by the [[Southern Association of Colleges and Schools]] (SACS). ==Academics== {{as of|2014}}, Alice Lloyd College has implemented 18 major degree programs and eight pre-professional programs into its curricula.{{cite web|title=Degrees & Majors|url=http://www.alc.edu/academics/degrees-majors/|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=23 July 2014}} The student-to-faculty ratio is 20:1. Ninety-five percent of Alice Lloyd College graduates are accepted into graduate and professional schools.{{cite news|title=Kentucky college receives big recognition|url=http://www.wkyt.com/wymtnews/headlines/100918749.html|accessdate=17 August 2010|newspaper=[[WYMT-TV]]|date=17 August 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819153154/http://www.wkyt.com/wymtnews/headlines/100918749.html|archivedate=19 August 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Seventy-five percent of Alice Lloyd College graduates are the first in their families to obtain an undergraduate degree.{{cite web|title=The Miracle on Caney Creek|url=http://www.alc.edu/donate/donate_about.php|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=11 July 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910173605/http://www.alc.edu/donate/donate_about.php|archivedate=10 September 2011|df=}} ==Rankings and reputation== Alice Lloyd College was ranked number 7 in Regional Colleges South and number 2 in Best Value Schools, as of the 2018 edition of Best Colleges.[https://www.usnews.com/best-colleges/alice-lloyd-college-1951] It was also listed as one of ''Forbes''{{'}} "100 Most Financially Fit Colleges".[https://www.forbes.com/pictures/eede45gkfh/alice-lloyd-college-2/#59beadd31a5e] ==Student finances and work-study== While Alice Lloyd College does not rely on any direct financial support from the state or federal governments, it does accept students using federal and state student financial aid such as federal [[Pell Grants]].{{cite web|url=http://www.alc.edu/financial_aid/fa_faq.php|title=Financial Aid – Frequently Asked Questions|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=2009-11-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090820051749/http://www.alc.edu/financial_aid/fa_faq.php|archivedate=2009-08-20|df=}} 16 percent of students receive education loans, for an average of approximately $800. According to the Project on Student Debt, each of Alice Lloyd's 2009 graduates carried an average debt of $6,500, which is well below the statewide average of $19,112 and the national average of $24,000.{{cite web|url=http://projectonstudentdebt.org/state_by_state-view2010.php?area=KY|title=Project on Student Debt: Kentucky|publisher=Project on Student Debt|accessdate=11 November 2010}}{{cite web|title=Student Debt and the Class of 2009|url=http://projectonstudentdebt.org/files/pub/classof2009.pdf|publisher=Project on Student Debt|accessdate=11 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101128082054/http://projectonstudentdebt.org/files/pub/classof2009.pdf| archivedate= 28 November 2010| deadurl= no}} The College, which accepted 262 of 6,337 applicants for the class of 2017, guarantees tuition to full-time students from an area consisting of 108 counties in [[Appalachia|Central Appalachia]].[https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/the-short-list-college/articles/2017-10-31/10-colleges-with-the-lowest-acceptance-rates?int=highereducation-rec 10 Colleges With the Lowest Acceptance Rates] US News. Retrieved November 8, 2017. Students are required to work in a [[work study|work-study]] program regardless of financial situation.{{cite web|url=http://www.alc.edu/financial_aid/fa_workstudy.php|title=Student Work Program|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=2009-11-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090812060615/http://www.alc.edu/financial_aid/fa_workstudy.php|archivedate=2009-08-12|df=}} They are given jobs such as janitorial staff, office assistant, tutor, craft maker, resident advisor, maintenance, grounds or working in the cafeteria (Hunger Din). In addition to on-campus jobs, students can work at off-campus outreach projects.{{cite web|title=The Purpose Road Philosophy|url=http://www.alc.edu/about/purpose.php|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=28 September 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917060245/http://alc.edu/about/purpose.php|archivedate=17 September 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|last=Andriotis|first=AnnaMaria|title=The Most Affordable Colleges in America|url=http://www.smartmoney.com/personal-finance/college-planning/the-most-affordable-colleges-in-america-1294330570608/?page=2|accessdate=7 January 2011|newspaper=SmartMoney|date=7 January 2011}} Students are required to work at least 160 hours per semester.{{cite book|title=Alice Lloyd College Student Work Handbook|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|pages=6|url=http://www.alc.edu/files/docs/Student-Work-Program-Handbook.pdf|access-date=2010-08-01|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706035138/http://www.alc.edu/files/docs/Student-Work-Program-Handbook.pdf|archive-date=2010-07-06|dead-url=yes|df=}} The college is one of eight [[work colleges]] in the [[United States]] and one of two in Kentucky ([[Berea College]] being the other) that have mandatory work-study programs. Students from 108 counties in the [[Appalachian Mountains]] region of Kentucky, [[Ohio]], [[Tennessee]], [[Virginia]] and [[West Virginia]] pay no tuition through the Appalachian Leaders College Scholarship.{{cite web|title=Central Appalachian 108-County Service Area|url=http://www.alc.edu/files/docs/Service-Area.pdf|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=24 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706065808/http://www.alc.edu/files/docs/Service-Area.pdf|archivedate=6 July 2010|df=}}{{cite web|title=Alice Lloyd College Service Area Map|url=http://www.alc.edu/files/images/alc-servicemap-lg.gif|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=1 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706034145/http://www.alc.edu/files/images/alc-servicemap-lg.gif|archivedate=6 July 2010|df=}} ==Student life== The dormitories house about 600 students, with rental prices averaging $1,900 annually.{{cite web|url=http://www.american-school-search.com/review/alice-lloyd-college|title=Alice Lloyd College: Review & Facts - American School Search|publisher=}} Alice Lloyd College requires students to live in gender-separated [[dormitories]] and only allows the opposite sex into a gender-specific dorm during "open houses," after room checks have been made. Room checks consist of two [[resident assistant|resident advisors]] going into each room and making sure that it is clean and it does not contain any illegal substances. The college is located in [[Knott County, Kentucky]], a [[dry county]],{{cite web|url=http://abc.ky.gov/Licensing/Wet%20Dry%20List%202015%2010.28.15.pdf|title=Wet Dry List 2015 10.28.15.pdf|date=28 October 2015|publisher=Kentucky Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control|accessdate=29 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123003045/http://abc.ky.gov/Licensing/Wet%20Dry%20List%202015%2010.28.15.pdf|archivedate=23 January 2016|df=}} thus alcoholic beverages are prohibited. Professional dress is required of all students on central campus until 2:00 p.m. every Tuesday and for all convocation programs.{{cite web|title=Student Life|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|location=Pippa Passes, Kentucky|url=http://www.alc.edu/student-life|accessdate=29 December 2015}} While this college is not affiliated with any [[religious denomination]], the college's mission statement emphasizes the role of [[Christianity|Christian]] values.{{cite web|url=http://www.alc.edu/about-us/alc-values/|title=ALC Values|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=29 December 2015}} In addition, the college offers coursework in [[religion]]{{cite web|url=http://www.alc.edu/academics/humanities/|title=Humanities|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=29 December 2015}} and has a chapter of [[Baptist Student Union|Baptist Collegiate Ministries]].{{cite web|url=http://www.alc.edu/student-life/campus-ministries/|title=Campus Ministries|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=29 December 2015}} The college [[choir]] is called the "Voices of Appalachia." The choir, formed in 1962, holds a tour annually in the spring, performing hymns and ballads. The choir has made several media appearances, including [[NBC]]'s ''[[Today (NBC program)|Today]]'' and ''[[CBS News Sunday Morning]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.alc.edu/alumni/the-voices-of-appalachia/|title=The Voices of Appalachia|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=29 December 2015}} The college offers a series of speakers and events called convocations. Students are required to attend six convocations per semester.{{cite web|url=http://www.alc.edu/academics/convocations/|title=Convocations|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=29 December 2015}} ==Campus== The Commodore Slone Building, at one time housing the science program and most recently the [[June Buchanan School]], the college's K-12 [[University-preparatory school|prep school]], was renovated to house the business program.{{cite web|url=http://www.wkyt.com/news/headlines/30587354.html|title=Business Programs To Expand At Alice Lloyd College|publisher=|access-date=2008-10-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523084256/http://www.wkyt.com/news/headlines/30587354.html|archive-date=2011-05-23|dead-url=yes|df=}} The Business & Technology Center was completed in the fall of 2009 and was dedicated on October 10, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.alcleadershipu.net/s/1021/index.aspx?sid=1021&gid=1&pgid=252&cid=942&ecid=942&crid=0&calpgid=61&calcid=798|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723010046/http://www.alcleadershipu.net/s/1021/index.aspx?sid=1021&gid=1&pgid=252&cid=942&ecid=942&crid=0&calpgid=61&calcid=798|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-07-23|title=Commodore Slone Building and Alice Lloyd Statue Celebration|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=2009-09-21}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alc.edu/news/newspage.php?subaction=showfull&id=1256680405&archive=&start_from=&ucat=1,3&|title=Appalachia Day Homecoming Recap|date=2009-10-27|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=2009-10-28}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Caney Cottage Scholarship== The college owns the H.N. and Frances C. Berger Residence Hall, also known as Caney Cottage, an apartment complex near the campus of the [[University of Kentucky]] in [[Lexington, Kentucky|Lexington]].{{cite web|url=http://www.alc.edu/academics/academic_scholarships.php|title=Scholarships|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=13 December 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090619065906/http://www.alc.edu/academics/academic_scholarships.php|archivedate=19 June 2009|df=}} Students who graduate from Alice Lloyd and are accepted into UK's [[graduate school]] can apply to live in the Caney Cottage rent, utility and parking free. Those who attend other graduate schools can apply for cash scholarships that go toward tuition costs.{{cite web|url=http://www.alc.edu/financial_aid/fa_scholarships.php|title=Financial Aid and Scholarships|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=2009-06-18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090620053748/http://www.alc.edu/financial_aid/fa_scholarships.php|archivedate=20 June 2009|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite news|last=Insko|first=Maisie|title=AEP donates $250,000 to ALC|url=http://www.wkyt.com/wymtnews/headlines/AEP_donates_250000_to_ALC_129840333.html|accessdate=14 September 2011|newspaper=[[WYMT-TV]]|date=14 September 2011}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=Willking1979 |fix-attempted=yes }} After graduate school, scholarship recipients must commit to service in the Appalachian region.{{cite book|title=Alice Lloyd College Catalog 2006-2008|pages=7, 24–25,|url=http://www.alc.edu/files/docs/APrg-CATALOG_06.pdf|accessdate=2009-06-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716111846/http://www.alc.edu/files/docs/APrg-CATALOG_06.pdf|archivedate=2011-07-16|df=}} ==Presidents== Since the death of Alice Lloyd in 1962, five men have taken the position of president of the Alice Lloyd College:[http://www.alc.edu/about/about_history.php History of Alice Lloyd College] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090619065826/http://www.alc.edu/about/about_history.php |date=2009-06-19 }} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Name ! Notes |- | 1963–77 | William S. Hayes | |- | 1977–88 | Jerry C. Davis | president of the [[College of the Ozarks]] |- | 1988–95 | M. Fred Mullinax | executive vice-president of the College of the Ozarks ''Springfield (MO) Business Journal'', September 23, 2008 |- | 1995–99 | Timothy T. Siebert | |- | 1999–present | Joe Alan Stepp | first native of [[Appalachia]] to become ALC's president |} ==Athletics== Alice Lloyd College teams are nicknamed the Eagles. The college is a member of the [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics]] (NAIA), primarily competing in the [[River States Conference]] (RSC). Men's sports include baseball, basketball, cross country, tennis and golf; women's sports include basketball, cheerleading, cross country, dance, softball, tennis, and volleyball.{{cite web|url=http://www.alc.edu/athletics/index.php|title=Intercollegiate Athletics|publisher=Alice Lloyd College|accessdate=2009-06-18| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090606155511/http://www.alc.edu/athletics/index.php| archivedate= 6 June 2009 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|title=Athletic News & Events: ALC Announces New Sports|url=http://www.alc.edu/news/athletics.php|accessdate=7 June 2010|date=1 June 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100628205950/http://www.alc.edu/news/athletics.php|archivedate=28 June 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} ==Notable alumni== {{Expand list|date=February 2011}} * [[Carl D. Perkins]], member of the [[U.S. House of Representatives]], 1949-1984 * [[Preston Spradlin]], basketball head coach at [[Morehead State Eagles men's basketball|Morehead State]], former assistant coach at [[Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball|Kentucky]] * Dr. Grady Stumbo (born 1945), A.A., Alice Lloyd College 1965, B.S. University of Kentucky 1967, M.D. University of Kentucky 1971;{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W4cFDAUqM5UC|title=The Public Papers of Governor Brereton C. Jones, 1991-1995|first=Brereton C.|last=Jones|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|via=Google Books}} Rockefeller Award winner;{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q27vC0mfTmgC|title=A College for Appalachia: Alice Lloyd on Caney Creek|first=P. David|last=Searles|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|via=Google Books}} head of [[Kentucky Democratic Party]] (1991–1995) ==See also== *[[June Buchanan School]], a [[K-12]] [[University-preparatory school|prep school]] on the campus *[[WWJD]]-FM, owned and operated by the college ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{Official website|www.alc.edu}} {{Kentucky Higher Education}} {{Work Colleges Consortium}} {{River States Conference navbox}} {{NCCAA Division I Mid-East navbox}} {{coord|37|20|9.3|N|82|52|24.94|W|display=title}} [[Category:Appalachian culture in Kentucky]] [[Category:Liberal arts colleges in Kentucky]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Knott County, Kentucky]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1923]] [[Category:Settlement schools]] [[Category:Universities and colleges accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools]] [[Category:1923 establishments in Kentucky]] [[Category:Alice Lloyd College| ]] [[Category:Education in Knott County, Kentucky]] [[Category:USCAA member institutions]] [[Category:Work colleges]]

{{Infobox organization | image = Alliance_for_Climate_Education_logo.jpg | formation = 2008 | type = [[Non-profit]] | purpose = Environmental education and youth advocacy | name = Alliance for Climate Education | abbreviation = ACE | location = United States of America | website = https://acespace.org }}
'''Alliance for Climate Education,''' or ACE, educates young people on the science of climate change and empowers them to take action. ACE is a [[501(c)3]] nonprofit that provides educational resources on climate science and justice, as well training for young climate leaders. Since 2008, ACE has reached more than 2,000,000 students nationwide.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://acespace.org/what-we-do|title=What We Do|website=Alliance for Climate Education|language=en|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref>
== Programs == === Education === ACE provides in-person assemblies at high schools nationwide. The assembly is noted for its engaging multimedia content, dynamic presenters, and effectiveness in connecting with hard-to-reach teen audiences.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://acespace.org/assembly|title=The ACE Assembly|website=Alliance for Climate Education|language=en|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref> A 2014 study by Stanford, Yale, and George Mason University showed that after viewing the live ACE Assembly, students demonstrated a 27% increase in climate science knowledge, more than one-third (38%) became more engaged on the issue of climate change, and the number of students who talked to parents or peers about climate change more than doubled.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Flora|first=June|year=2014|title=Evaluation of a national high school entertainment education program: The Alliance for Climate Education|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10584-014-1274-1|journal=Climatic Change|volume=127|pages=419–434|via=Springer|doi=10.1007/s10584-014-1274-1}}</ref>
ACE also offers [https://ourclimateourfuture.org/ Our Climate Our Future], an online multimedia resource for schools. Using animation, music, video, and interactivity, it teaches students the latest climate science and inspire young people to take action.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ourclimateourfuture.org|title=Our Climate Our Future|website=Our Climate Our Future|language=en|access-date=2017-03-26}}</ref>
=== Leadership === ACE gives students opportunities to take action on climate change, digitally as well as in person. Through online advocacy, ACE encourages young people nationwide to speak up on climate issues. ACE works with regional partners to connect youth leaders to climate campaigns where they can have immediate, real world impact. The Action Fellowship training program gives young people the knowledge, skills, and confidence to be powerful climate leaders.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://acespace.org/fellowship|title=ACE Action Fellowship|website=Alliance for Climate Education|language=en|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref>
ACE youth leaders have lobbied elected officials for pro-climate policies including energy efficiency,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://acespace.org/blog/students-meet-senators-during-spring-break|title=Students Meet With Senators During Spring Break|website=Alliance for Climate Education|language=en|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref> fossil fuel divestment,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://acespace.org/blog/youth-lead-charge-passing-boston%E2%80%99s-landmark-fossil-fuel-divestment-resolution|title=Youth Lead the Charge on Passing Boston’s Landmark Fossil Fuel Divestment Resolution|website=Alliance for Climate Education|language=en|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref> and renewable energy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nextgenamerica.org/blog/students-step-up-for-climate/|title=Students Step Up for Climate - NextGen Climate America|date=2015-06-10|work=NextGen Climate America|access-date=2017-03-23|language=en-US}}</ref> They have also spoken at high-profile events such as the United Nations,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.connect4climate.org/article/ace-fellows-speak-un-high-level-climate-events|title=ACE Fellows Speak at UN and Cover High-level Climate Events {{!}} #Connect4Climate|website=Connect4Climate|language=en|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref> Bioneers,<ref>{{Citation|last=Bioneers|title=Jasmyn Mitchell - Youth Leadership {{!}} Bioneers|date=2015-11-12|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hv2coAJxrac|accessdate=2017-03-23}}</ref> and Climate Action 2016.<ref>{{Citation|last=Alliance for Climate Education|title=HS Junior Jasmine Gregory with Bill Nye at Climate Action 2016|date=2016-05-10|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k8403yyr-ao|accessdate=2017-03-23}}</ref>
== Awards == Awards for ACE's work include the White House Champion of Change Award for Climate Literacy, the National Center for Science Education Friend of the Planet Award, the AQMD Award for Public Education on Air Quality Issues, the EPA Environmental Merit Award, and the Climate Change Communicator of the Year Award.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://acespace.org/awards|title=Awards & Recognition|website=Alliance for Climate Education|language=en|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Climate change in the United States]] * [[Education in the United States]] * [[Environmental groups and resources serving K–12 schools]]
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.acespace.org/ Alliance for Climate Education] * [https://ourclimateourfuture.org/ Our Climate Our Future]

{{Other uses of|Bogoliubov Prize}} '''The Bogoliubov Prize for young scientists''' is an award offered to young researchers in [[theoretical physics]] by the [[Joint Institute for Nuclear Research]] (JINR), an international intergovernmental organization located in Dubna, Russia. The award is issued in memory of the physicist and mathematician [[Nikolay Bogoliubov]].
The prize is awarded to young (up to 33-year-old) researchers for "outstanding contributions in fields of [[theoretical physics]] related to Bogoliubov's scientific interests".<ref>[http://cerncourier.com/main/article/39/3/19 Bogoliubov prize for young scientists] at CERN COURIER</ref> The awardee is one who has demonstrated "early scientific maturity" and whose results are recognized worldwide and peer-reviewed. The laureates generally emulate Bogoliubov's own skill in using sophisticated mathematics to attempt to solve concrete physical problems (mostly in the fields of [[nonlinear dynamics]], [[statistical physics]], [[quantum field theory]] and elementary [[particle physics]]).
==Jury== The jury is presided by the theoretical physicist [[Dmitry Shirkov]], who co-authored many works with Nikolay Bogoliubov.
==Laureates== * 1999 Oleg Shvedov ([[Moscow State University]], Russia): for a series of works on asymptotical methods in statistical physics and quantum field theory. * 2001 Evgenii Ivashkevich ([[JINR]], Russia): for a series of works on analytical methods in non-equilibrium statistical mechanics. * 2005 [[Aurélien Barrau]] (the Laboratory of sub-atomic physics and cosmology and [[Joseph Fourier University]], Grenoble, France): for a series of works on astrophysics and cosmology.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bogolyubov Prize For Young Scientists}} [[Category:Science and technology in Russia]] [[Category:Physics education]] [[Category:Physics awards]] [[Category:Awards with age limits]]

'''Charles Sumner Richardson''' (1854~1855 – 1904) was the first president of South Dakota's [[normal school]], Madison Normal, that later became [[Dakota State University]].<ref name="Lowry-3">{{Cite book|author=Lowry, Vayne Arnold |year=1984 |title=Forty Years at General Beadle (1922–1962) |location=[[Madison, South Dakota]] |publisher=Dakota State University |page=3 |url=http://dlsd.sdln.net/cdm/ref/collection/university/id/8584 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|author=Olson, Bonnie |year=2007 |title=Historical Calendar of Dakota State University (1881–2007) |location=Madison, South Dakota |publisher=Dakota State University }}</ref>
Richardson was born to Issac E. and Susan M. B. Richardson about 1854<ref>{{Cite web|title=Isaac E Richardson |work=United States Census, 1880 |url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:MF3B-Q31 |subscription=yes}}</ref> in [[Hartford, Maine]],<ref name="NH-marr">{{Cite web|title=Charles S. Richardson |work=New Hampshire Marriages, 1720-1920 |url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:FDL2-SM1}}</ref> where he grew up.<ref name="Colby-cat">{{Cite book |author=Colby College |title=Colby College Catalogue 1881 - 1882 |year=1881 |publisher=Colby College |page=34 |url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/0565/f5663ff4a096ed16fc47dfffaa66700e926a.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161215184006/https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/0565/f5663ff4a096ed16fc47dfffaa66700e926a.pdf |archivedate=15 December 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> He attended the nearby [[Colby College]] in [[Waterville, Maine]] where he graduated in 1883;<ref name="Lowry-3" /><ref name="Colby-cat" /> whereupon he took the job of organizing the newly created Madison Normal School in South Dakota. He was president of the school from 1883 to 1887.<ref name="Lowry-3" /> In 1884 he married Edith May Adams.<ref name="NH-marr" /> Richardson was succeeded as president by William F. Gorrie of [[Watertown, South Dakota]], who assumed office in September 1887.<ref>{{harvnb|Lowry|1984|page=9}}</ref>
After leaving Madison, Richardson took graduate course work at Harvard in chemistry and mineralogy, followed by accepting appointment at [[Olivet College]] in [[Olivet, Michigan]] where he briefly was a professor of mathematics and physics.<ref name="SLH-obit">{{Cite news|title=Richardson of Richardson & Adams dies as a result of an operation |date=25 June 1904 |newspaper=Salt Lake Herald |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058130/1904-06-25/ed-1/seq-2/#date1=06%2F21%2F1904&index=0&date2=07%2F23%2F1904&searchType=advanced&language=&sequence=0&lccn=sn85058130&words=Charles+Richardson+Sumner&proxdistance=5&rows=20&ortext=&proxtext=&phrasetext=Charles+Sumner+Richardson&andtext=&dateFilterType=range&page=1 }}</ref> In 1891 he moved to [[Salt Lake City, Utah|Salt Lake City]] due to his interest in mining. He became involved with a number of mines in the [[Bingham Canyon, Utah|Bingham Canyon mining district]], notably the Old Jordan and South Galena mines.<ref name="SLH-obit" /> In 1895, he moved to [[Anaconda, Montana]] where with a Mr. Olson, Richardson together with his brother-in-law, Charles Francis Adams,<ref>{{Cite magazine|title=New Hampshire Necrology: Thomas A. Adams |year=1906 |magazine=Granite Monthly: A New Hampshire Magazine |volume=38 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Q2ASAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA487&lpg=PA487 487] }}</ref> ran a merchantile, suppling clothes and other dry goods to the miners. In 1899, he and his brother-in-law returned to Salt Lake City and opened the firm of Richardson & Adams. Richardson & Adams primarily ran an upscale clothing store (clothier) in downtown Salt Lake City,<ref name="SLH-obit" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Utah State Gazetteer and Business Directory, 1903-1904, Volume 2 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=az9OAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA5-PA442&lpg=RA5-PA442 399] }}</ref> but it still also held a number of mining claims.<ref>{{Cite journal|year=1910 |title=Dips, Spurs and Angles |journal=The Salt Lake Mining Review |volume=11 |issue=22 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=vu4-AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA21-PA34 34] }}</ref>
The Richardson Hall dorm at Dakota State was named after him in 1970.<ref name="bio">{{Cite web |title=DSU Archives: Professor Charles S. Richardson |publisher=Dakota State University |url=http://archives.dsu.edu/index.php/key-facts/university-presidents/richardson/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313105025/http://archives.dsu.edu/index.php/key-facts/university-presidents/richardson/ |archivedate=13 March 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> He died on June 24, 1904 in Omaha, Nebraska,<ref name="bio"/><ref name="SLH-obit" /> and was buried in the Mount Olivet Cemetery, in Salt Lake City, Utah.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Charles Sumner Richardson |publisher=Find a Grave |url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/41778238}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2014}} '''Christopher John Roper''' [[Order of Australia|AM]] (born 25 December 1944) is the Director of the [[St James' Church, Sydney|St James’ Institute]]. He is a former Adjunct Professor of the [[City University of Hong Kong]], a former Director of the [[Sydney Law School|College of Law Sydney]] and a former Professor of the [[College of Law|College of Law England and Wales]].<ref name="Roper">Who's Who in Australia (Crown Content Melb, 2007) pp 1769: Roper, Christoper John (1944 – )</ref>
==Education== Roper attended [[Newington College]] (1955-1961) <ref>Newington College Register of Past Students 1863-1998 (Syd, 1999) pp54</ref> and is an arts and law graduate of the [[University of Sydney]] [[Sydney Law School|Law School]]. He has an honours master's degree in education. Later Roper studied theology at [[Trinity College (University of Melbourne)]].<ref name="Roper"/>
==Legal career== After working as a lawyer, Roper began a career in professional legal education. He was the Executive Director of the Leo Cussen Institute in Melbourne and later the Director of [[The College of Law (Australia)|the College of Law]] in Sydney. After working as the Director of Education of [[King & Wood Mallesons]] he became the first Director of The Centre for Legal Education. Roper then returned to the College of Law and developed an alliance between the Colleges of Law in England, Australia and New Zealand.<ref name="Roper"/>
==Honours== In the [[Australia Day]] Honours List of 1999, Roper was made a Member of the [[Order of Australia]] in the General Division "for service to the development of continuing legal education".<ref name=Honour>{{cite web | title =It's an Honour | publisher =Australian Government | url =http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=882214&search_type=quick&showInd=true | accessdate = 22 January 2013 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Roper, Christopher}} [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from New South Wales]] [[Category:University of Sydney alumni]] [[Category:People educated at Newington College]] [[Category:People educated at Trinity College (University of Melbourne)]] [[Category:Members of the Order of Australia]] [[Category:Australian lawyers]] [[Category:Australian educators]] [[Category:Legal educators]]
{{Australia-law-bio-stub}}

'''Clarion''' is a six-week workshop for aspiring [[science fiction]] and [[fantasy]] writers. Originally an outgrowth of [[Damon Knight]] and [[Kate Wilhelm]]'s [[Milford Writer's Workshop|Milford Writers' Conference]], held at their home in [[Milford, Pennsylvania]], United States, it was founded in 1968 by [[Robin Wilson (author)|Robin Scott Wilson]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wright|first1=Anders|title=Project Triton: New Sci-Fi Colony|url=http://ucsdmag.ucsd.edu/magazine/vol5no2/features/projecttriton.htm|website=UCSD Alumni|publisher=UCSanDiego|accessdate=6 September 2015|date=May 2008}}</ref> at [[Clarion University of Pennsylvania|Clarion State College]] in [[Pennsylvania]]. Knight and Wilhelm were among the first teachers at the workshop.<ref name=Wilhelm>[[Kate Wilhelm|Wilhelm, Kate]], ''Storyteller: Writing Lessons and More from 27 Years of the Clarion Writers' Workshop'', [[Small Beer Press]], 2005 {{ISBN|978-1-931520-16-4}}</ref>
In 1972, the workshop moved to [[Michigan State University]]. It moved again, in 2006, to the [[University of California, San Diego]].<ref name=Jagoda>Barry Jagoda, [http://ucsdnews.ucsd.edu/thisweek/2006/dec/12_18_clarion.asp "Top Science Fiction Writers' Program Comes to UC San Diego"], ''This Week at UCSD'', December 18, 2006</ref>
[[File:Clarionites at play.jpg|right|thumb|Clarionites at Play (photograph by Keyan Bowes)]]
== Other Clarion Workshops == Independently-operated workshops which share the Clarion name and follow its founding principles include: * [[Clarion West Writers Workshop]], founded in Seattle, Washington in 1971 by [[Vonda N. McIntyre]]. It has been held annually since 1984. * Clarion South Writers Workshop was held at [[Griffith University]] in Brisbane, Australia. It was founded in 2004 and ran biennially. In 2009, Clarion South lost its venue, although the workshop was held that year. In March 2011, Clarion South organizers announced that future workshops were "on hold indefinitely."<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.clarionsouth.org/|title = Workshop Update|date = March 2011|accessdate = |website = Clarion South|publisher = |last = |first = |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130328142743/http://www.clarionsouth.org/|archivedate = March 28, 2013|dead-url = yes}}</ref>
== See also == * [[List of Clarion Writers Workshop Instructors]] * [[List of Clarion Writers Workshop alumni]] * [[List of Clarion South Writers Workshop Instructors]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==Further reading==
*{{cite journal | last1=Knight | first1=Damon | authorlink=Damon Knight | title=I Remember Clarion | journal=Isaac Asimov's Science Fiction Magazine | date=March 1990 | volume=14 | issue=3 | pages=20–28 }}
==External links== * [http://clarion.ucsd.edu Clarion official website] *[http://libraries.ucsd.edu/speccoll/findingaids/mss0681.html Clarion Science Fiction and Fantasy Workshop: Archive of Stories by Participants] MSS 681. [http://libraries.ucsd.edu/collections/sca/ Special Collections & Archives], UC San Diego Library.
{{SpecFicWorkshops}}

{{Infobox organization | name = CyArk | native_name = | image = [[Image:Cyark logo.png|250px|The ''CyArk'' logo.]] | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = 2003 <!-- e.g. use {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | founder = [[Ben Kacyra]] | extinction = <!-- e.g. use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for non-profit org) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = [[Digital preservation]] of [[World Heritage Site|cultural heritage sites]] and architecture | headquarters = [[Oakland, California]] | location = | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | region = | services = | products = CyArk 3D Heritage Archive | methods = [[Laser scanning]], [[3D modeling|digital modeling]] | fields = | membership = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | revenue = | disbursements = | expenses = | endowment = | staff = | volunteers = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{url|cyark.org}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} '''CyArk''' is a [[501(c)(3)]] nonprofit organization located in [[Oakland, California]], United States. The organization's website refers to it as a "digital archive of the world's heritage sites for preservation and education". Its official mission statement is "Digitally preserving cultural heritage sites through collecting, archiving and providing open access to data created by [[laser scanning]], [[3D modeling|digital modeling]], and other state-of-the-art technologies."
CyArk's founder, [[Ben Kacyra]], stated during his speech at the 2011 [[TED Conference]] that the organization was created in response to increasing human and natural threats to heritage sites, and to ensure the "collective human memory" is not lost while making it available through modern dissemination tools like the internet and mobile platforms.<ref>[http://www.ted.com/talks/ben_kacyra_ancient_wonders_captured_in_3d.html Video of Ben Kacyra's speech at the TED 2011 conference]</ref>
The organization is known for its work with a number of partners in producing high-quality digital scanning of [[World Heritage Sites]], such as [[Angkor Wat]], [[Pompeii]], [[Chichen Itza]], the [[Eastern Qing tombs]], [[Nineveh]], the [[Antonine Wall]], [[Mount Rushmore]], and many others.<ref name = "jbrown">{{Cite news | issue = March | last = Brown | first = John |author2=Elizabeth Lee | title = Ancient History Meets New Technology | work = Professional Surveyor Magazine | accessdate = 2014-10-11 | date = 2008 | url = http://archives.profsurv.com/magazine/article.aspx?i=2083 }}</ref><ref name = "elee">{{Cite news | volume = Volume 7 | issue = No. 7 | pages = 10–19 | last = Lee | first = Elizabeth | title = Scanning Rushmore - Digitizing the Legacy | work = The American Surveyor | accessdate = 2014-10-11 | date = October 2010 | url = http://www.amerisurv.com/emag/2010/Vol7No7/ }}</ref><ref name = "luccio">{{Cite news | issue = July | last = Luccio | first = Matteo | title = Surveying Cultural Heritage | work = Professional Surveyor Magazine | accessdate = 2014-10-11 | date = 2013 | url = http://archives.profsurv.com/magazine/article.aspx?i=71361 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | title = CyArk Projects | work = CyArk | accessdate = 2014-10-11 | url = http://cyark.org/projects/ }}</ref>
The organization seeks to preserve 500 World Heritage Sites in the next five years.<ref name="cheves">{{Cite news | last = Cheves | first = Marc | title = Monumental Challenge: Ben Kacyra's Remarkable Perseverance | work = LiDAR News | accessdate = 2014-10-11 | date = 2014-10-01 | url = http://www.lidarnews.com/content/view/10977/198/ | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141030143514/http://www.lidarnews.com/content/view/10977/198/ | archivedate = 2014-10-30 | df = }}</ref>
==History== [[Image:Cyark Tikal Temple II.jpg|thumb|right|Profile of [[Tikal Temple II]]]] CyArk was founded in 2003 by [[Iraqi American|Iraqi expatriate]] and [[civil engineer]] Ben Kacyra. In the 1990s, Kacyra was instrumental in the invention and marketing of the first truly portable [[3D Scanner|laser scanner]]. The scanner, called the [[Cyrax (HDS system)|Cyrax]], was designed for surveying purposes, and was produced by Cyra Technologies.<ref name = "abate">{{Cite news | last = Abate | first = Tom | title = Laser mapping tool traces ancient sites - Device made for contractors helps archaeologists create first-ever digital blueprints | work = SFGate - Innovations | accessdate = 2014-10-11 | date = 2007-07-22 | url = http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/INNOVATIONS-Laser-mapping-tool-traces-ancient-2579950.php }}</ref>
In 2001, Cyra Technologies and all rights to the invention were sold to the Swiss firm [[Leica Geosystems]].<ref>{{Cite web | title = History | work = [[Leica Geosystems]] | accessdate = 2014-10-11 | url = http://www.leica-geosystems.com/en/History_834.htm }}</ref>
After sale of the company, Ben Kacyra dedicated his energy to using the new technology to document archaeological and cultural heritage resources, and to the CyArk organization.<ref name = "eapowell">{{Cite news | volume = Volume 62 | issue = No 3 | last = Powell | first = Eric A | title = The Past in High-Def | work = Archaeology Magazine | accessdate = 2014-10-11 | date = May–June 2009 | url = http://archive.archaeology.org/0905/etc/high_def.html }}</ref>
CyArk's primary focus has been the documentation and digital preservation of threatened ancient and historical architecture. This architecture includes sites such as Colorado's [[Mesa Verde]], Italy's [[Pompeii]], Wyoming's [[Fort Laramie]], and Kacyra's native [[Mosul]] in Iraq – also known as the biblical [[Assyria]]n city of [[Nineveh]].
CyArk has generated a fairly large amount of publicity since its inception. Initially, this was in part due to the relevance of Kacyra's life story to the ongoing [[Iraq War]], during which much of the country's cultural patrimony was destroyed amidst a [[Archaeological looting in Iraq|spasm of looting]] and heavy military damage to important historical sites such as [[Babylon]] and [[Samarra]]. As the public face of the CyArk organization, Ben Kacyra became a popular speaker at conferences such as [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sD7XUwxAuEw Google’s Zeitgeist (2008)], and [http://www.ted.com/talks/ben_kacyra_ancient_wonders_captured_in_3d.html TEDGlobal (2011)], describing his life story and the potential of digital preservation to save the "collective treasure" of global heritage. In recent years, however, he has taken on more of an advisory role, while the independent non-profit organization CyArk has gathered considerable momentum.
"In October of 2013, CyArk launched the CyArk 500 Challenge."<ref name = "cheves" /> The organization announced that it seeks to "digitally preserve 500 heritage sites in five years."<ref name = "cyark2014">{{Cite web | title = CyArk 500 Annual Summit 2014 | work = Digital meets Culture | accessdate = 2014-10-09 | date = 2014-10-07 | url = http://www.digitalmeetsculture.net/article/cyark-500-annual-summit-2014/ }}</ref>
As of 2014, CyArk has become a major entity in the historic preservationist and cultural resource/heritage management communities. The 2014 CyArk 500 Annual Summit was held at the [[National Archives Building]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] The theme was "Democratising cultural heritage: Enabling access to information, technology and support."<ref name = "cyark2014" />
==Project focus== [[Image:Cyark Tikal Temple II 3D.jpg|thumb|right|3-dimensional projection of [[Tikal Temple II]]]] According to CyArk's mission statement, the organization is
{{quote|dedicated to the preservation of cultural heritage sites through the CyArk 3D Heritage Archive, an internet archive which is the repository for heritage site data developed through laser scanning, digital modeling, and other state-of-the-art spatial technologies.}}
CyArk's digital data may be useful for professionals monitoring and managing gradual architectural deterioration at cultural sites.<ref>Interview with Ben Kacyra in National Geographic (October 2010)</ref> This data could also make it possible to generate blueprints for reconstruction following catastrophic events, such as the [[Afghan Taliban]]'s notorious demolition of the [[Bamiyan Buddhas]] in 2001 or the 2010 destruction by suspected arson of the [[Kasubi Tombs|Royal Tombs of Kasubi]], [[Uganda]]. The Kasubi Tombs were digitally preserved by CyArk a year before their demise, providing a lasting digital record and potential blueprint for reconstruction.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Preston | first = Elizabeth | title = The Big Idea - Laser Preservation | work = National Geographic Magazine | accessdate = 2014-10-11 | date = December 2011 | url = http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/big-idea/15/laser-preservation }}</ref>
CyArk offers a publicly accessible web archive for the archaeological sites it has studied. The archive includes a short film introduction for each site, a slideshow of site history, and information about the digital preservation process used. A site plan displays geo-located multimedia, which is also accessible in an image gallery, along with three-dimensional images of site details such as rooms and profiles, and computer-generated reconstructions. The three dimensional images are often taken from a "[[point cloud]]" image showing the raw scan data.<ref name = "pbswiredscience">[https://www.pbs.org/kcet/wiredscience/story/91-laser_archaeology.html PBS' ''Wired Science'' segment on CyArk], November 2007</ref> CyArk has granted permission for reuse of some of the images through a [[Creative Commons]] Attribution/Share-Alike license.
According to CyArk's online mission statement, the dissemination of free digital content about heritage sites can help encourage additional visits by tourists, and invigorate communities with revenue from [[cultural tourism]]. Youth and educators will benefit from free, publicly accessible historical and site information, including some Creative Commons-licensed content. And finally, the creation of digital records ensures not only that the sites will never be lost forever; it also provides a digital resource to facilitate the continued mining of information over time as technologies and methods of information extraction evolve.
== Selected list of projects == *[http://archive.cyark.org/ancient-merv-intro Ancient Merv], a major crossroads along the ancient silk road in Turkmenistan *[http://archive.cyark.org/ancient-thebes-intro Ancient Thebes] and the Ramesseum/Necropolis of Ramses II, Egypt *[http://archive.cyark.org/angkor-intro Angkor Wat]'s western causeway and Banteay Kdei areas, Cambodia *[http://archive.cyark.org/bab-albarqiyya-intro The Bab al-Barqiyya Gate], a portion of the Ayyubid Wall in Cairo, Egypt *[http://archive.cyark.org/carmelite-church-of-weissenburg-intro A Carmelite Church] in Weissenburg, Germany *[http://archive.cyark.org/cathedral-of-beauvais-intro Beauvais Cathedral], a Gothic masterwork in France *[http://archive.cyark.org/chavin-de-huantar-intro Chavin De Huantar], 3500-year-old capital of the Chavin culture, Peru <ref>{{Cite news | issue = March | last = Risvetski | first = John | title = Laser Scanning for Cultural Heritage Applications | work = Professional Surveyor Magazine | accessdate = 2014-10-11 | date = 2006 | url = http://archives.profsurv.com/magazine/article.aspx?i=1555 }}</ref> *[http://archive.cyark.org/chichen-itza-intro Chichen Itza], ancient Yucatán Maya center and pilgrimage site, Mexico <ref name = "jbrown" /> *[http://archive.cyark.org/deadwood-intro Deadwood], the legendary Old West city in South Dakota, United States *[http://archive.cyark.org/fort-conger-intro Fort Conger], a 19th-century Arctic exploration camp located on Northeastern Ellesmere Island, Nunavut, Canada. *[http://archive.cyark.org/fort-laramie-intro Fort Laramie], historic center of the Plains Indian Wars and the Oregon Trail, United States *[http://archive.cyark.org/hypogeum-of-the-volumnis-intro The Hypogeum of the Volumnis], an intact Etruscan tomb near Perugia, Italy *[http://archive.cyark.org/mesa-verde-intro Mesa Verde]'s Spruce Tree House, Square Tower House, and Fire Temple, ancestral Puebloan cliff structures in Colorado, United States <ref name = "pbswiredscience" /> *[[Monte Alban]], the capital of the ancient Zapotecs of Oaxaca, Mexico <ref name = "eapowell" /><ref>[http://archive.cyark.org/monte-alban-intro Monte Alban], CyArk website</ref> *[http://archive.cyark.org/nineveh-region-intro Nineveh], imperial capital of the Assyrian Empire, Iraq *[http://archive.cyark.org/piazza-del-duomo-pisa-intro Piazza Del Duomo]'s Baptistery, Cathedral, and Campanile (also known as the Leaning Tower of Pisa), Italy *[http://archive.cyark.org/pompeii-intro Pompeii], ancient Roman city buried under the volcanic eruption of Mt. Vesuvius, Italy. The CyArk website states that this project was also the first time laser scanning was used to document a cultural heritage site. *[http://archive.cyark.org/presidio-of-san-francisco-intro The Presidio of San Francisco], a historic military base, United States *[http://archive.cyark.org/qalat-albahrain-intro Qal’at al-Bahrain], a 14th-century Portuguese fort built atop the remains of the ancient Dilmun civilization's hilltop capitol, Bahrain *[[Rani ki vav]], the largest [[stepwell]] in India, in the town of [[Patan, Gujarat|Patan]], [[Gujarat]] <ref name = "luccio" /> *[http://archive.cyark.org/rapa-nui-intro Rapa Nui (Easter Island)], scans of the famous monuments and lesser-known structures of this very isolated Polynesian culture site, Chile *[http://archive.cyark.org/roman-baths-intro Roman Baths of Weissenburg], one of the best-preserved examples of Thermae along the remote borders of the Roman Empire, Germany *[http://archive.cyark.org/royal-tombs-at-kasubi-intro Royal Kasubi Tombs], culturally vital mausoleum of the last four Bugandan Kings, Uganda. The Tombs were scanned and documented by CyArk in 2009 then largely destroyed by a fire in 2010, and data from the scans will be used for reconstruction efforts. *[http://archive.cyark.org/saint-sebald-church-intro Saint Sebald Church], a medieval cathedral in Nuremberg that was heavily damaged during WWII but retained enough original architecture to allow for digital reconstructions, Germany *[http://archive.cyark.org/saint-trophime-intro Church and Cloister of Saint-Trophime], a former cathedral in Arles, France that contains some of the world's most notable Romanesque facades *[http://archive.cyark.org/salvador-da-bahia-intro The Pelourinho] of Salvador da Bahia, historic downtown district of Brazil's original capitol *[http://archive.cyark.org/stone-bridge-regensburg-intro Stone Bridge] of Regensburg, 800-year-old bridge across the Danube, Germany *[http://archive.cyark.org/tambo-colorado-intro Tambo Colorado], an adobe-built strategic center of the ancient Inca empire, Peru *[http://archive.cyark.org/tikal-intro Tikal], one of the most important and longest-occupied cities of the ancient Maya world, Guatemala *[http://archive.cyark.org/tudor-place-info Tudor Place], a Federal-style neoclassical mansion that served as home to six generations of George Washington's immediate descendants
The CyArk website also offers a world map of the hazards which global heritage sites face, such as earthquakes and [[Current sea level rise|sea level rise]] due to [[global warming]].
== Funding and partnerships == Initially, CyArk was fully supported by the Kacyra family and their Kacyra Family Foundation.<ref name = "abate"/>
CyArk is now primarily funded through individual project funding, corporate in-kind support, and foundation grants/donations. Corporate funders as of 2014 include [[Microsoft]], [[IBM]], [[Iron Mountain Incorporated|Iron Mountain]], [[Autodesk]], and [[Trimble Navigation]].<ref name = "cheves" />
CyArk has also established working relationships with project partners in engineering, media, and academia, including Christofori und Partner and [[PBS]]. At [[UC Berkeley]], the organization coordinated an internship program with the department of Anthropology in 2006-2007. CyArk is currently an approved work-study employer for Cal students.
As of October 2011, the already-existing partnerships with the United States' [[National Park Service]] (NPS), the United Kingdom's [[Historic Scotland]] (HS), [[World Monuments Fund]], and Mexico's [[Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia|Instituto Nacional de Antropología]] y Historia ([[INAH]]) had been greatly expanded,<ref>[http://archive.cyark.org/community Updates from CyArk, 2011], CyArk website</ref> with upcoming projects that include Mexico's Teotihuacan,<ref>[http://archive.cyark.org/teotihuacan-and-the-pyramid-of-quetzalcoatl-blog Teotihuacan], CyArk website</ref> Scotland's [[Rosslyn Chapel]],<ref>[http://archive.cyark.org/cyark-to-host-data-from-rosslyn-chapel-blog Rosslyn Chapel], CyArk website</ref> Iraq's [[Babylon]], and the U.S.' [[Mount Rushmore|Mount Rushmore National Memorial]].<ref name = "elee" /><ref>[http://archive.cyark.org/managing-a-digital-mount-rushmore-blog Mount Rushmore], CyArk website</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{commons category}} *'''[http://www.cyark.org CyArk Website]''' *{{TED talk|ben_kacyra_ancient_wonders_captured_in_3d|Ancient Wonders captured in 3D|Ben Kacyra}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sD7XUwxAuEw Video of Ben Kacyra's presentation on CyArk at Google's Annual partner forum, Zeitgeist, in 2008] *[http://archive.cyark.org/hazard-map Hazard map showing variable sea level rise and earthquake impacts], developed by CyArk to demonstrate potential impact of climate change (and earthquakes) on [[World Heritage Sites]] *[https://dx.doi.org/10.11141/ia.30.1 F. Limp et al. 2011 'Developing a 3-D Digital Heritage Ecosystem: from object to representation and the role of a virtual museum in the 21st century', Internet Archaeology 30.] *[http://www.aia.org/aiarchitect/thisweek07/0525/0525d_pw.cfm ''AIArchitect'' article on Cyark Work at Tudor Place, May 2007] *[http://www.archaeologychannel.org/content/video/cyarkpompeii_700kW.html ''The Archaeology Channel'' video on the CyArk work at Pompeii]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cyark}} [[Category:3D imaging|Scanner]] [[Category:Archaeological organisations]] [[Category:Heritage organizations]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in California]] [[Category:Organizations based in Oakland, California]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2002]] [[Category:2002 establishments in California]]
